title: The effects of underwater pressure on the body - Neosha S Kashef

multiple-choice.question: What type of bodily damage is caused by rapid changes in pressure, which can cause a fish's eyes to bulge out of their sockets and its stomach to project out of its mouth?
According to Boyle's gas law, what happens to air-filled spaces, like a rockfish's swim bladder or human lungs, as they descend deeper?
What is the condition called when the air in a fish's swim bladder begins to expand as it is quickly reeled up to the surface, forcing its stomach out of its mouth and its eyes out of their sockets?
What is the name of the law that states the amount of a gas that dissolves in a liquid is proportional to its partial pressure?
What is decompression sickness, also known as the bends?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition caused by rapid changes in pressure that causes a fish's eyes to bulge out of their sockets and its stomach to project out of its mouth

options.label: B
options.text: A condition caused by the built-up nitrogen in a diver's tissues forming microbubbles in their blood and joints

options.label: C
options.text: A condition caused by the air in a fish's swim bladder expanding as it is quickly reeled up to the surface

options.label: D
options.text: A condition caused by the pressure of the water on a fish's body

multiple-choice.question: How do divers avoid falling victim to decompression sickness?

options.label: A
options.text: By rising quickly to the surface

options.label: B
options.text: By taking decompression stops along the way

options.label: C
options.text: By using a descending device to lower themselves to the right depth

options.label: D
options.text: By breathing out as they ascend

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of recompression for a fish to recover from barotrauma?

options.label: A
options.text: To release the built-up gas in its body

options.label: B
options.text: To allow the fish to swim back down on its own

options.label: C
options.text: To return the fish to its habitat and allow it to heal

options.label: D
options.text: To pierce its stomach with a needle

multiple-choice.question: What is the common myth about treating a fish with barotrauma?

options.label: A
options.text: That piercing its stomach with a needle will let air escape

options.label: B
options.text: That releasing it at the right depth will allow it to swim back down on its own

options.label: C
options.text: That using a descending device will lower it to the right depth

options.label: D
options.text: That breathing out as it ascends will release the built-up gas

title: What did democracy really mean in Athens? - Melissa Schwartzberg

multiple-choice.question: How were most offices filled in ancient Athenian democracy?

options.label: B
options.text: Through a lottery from a pool of citizen volunteers.

multiple-choice.question: What was the principle behind Athenian democracy that encouraged wide participation?

options.label: A
options.text: Ho boulomenos, or anyone who wishes.

options.label: B
options.text: Ho boulomenos, or anyone who is wealthy.

options.label: C
options.text: Ho boulomenos, or anyone who is educated.

options.label: D
options.text: Ho boulomenos, or anyone who is a citizen.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the governing council in ancient Athens that set the agenda and evaluated proposals?
What was the process of randomized selection used in ancient Athens?
What positions in ancient Athens were filled by elections?
What was the pool of eligible citizens in ancient Athens?
Who was excluded from full citizenship in ancient Athens?
What was the central feature of the democratic ideology of Athens?

options.label: B
options.text: Civic participation was the duty of all citizens.

options.label: C
options.text: Civic participation was only for the wealthy.

options.label: D
options.text: Civic participation was only for the educated.

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem with the Athenian system of government according to Plato?

options.label: C
options.text: It was anarchic and run by fools.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the democratic principle behind sortition still survives today?

title: Where did Earthâ€™s water come from? - Zachary Metz

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique characteristic of water that makes it easy to take its presence for granted?

options.label: C
options.text: It has no taste, color, or smell.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a solid at room temperature.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the Earth's surface is covered by water?
What is the process by which stars create heavier elements like oxygen and carbon?
What happens to water molecules when stars eventually collapse and explode into supernovas?

options.label: B
options.text: They are spread across the universe and combined into new compounds.

options.label: C
options.text: They are absorbed by the Earth's atmosphere.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the process by which molten rock in the Earth's core releases volcanic gases to the surface, creating a layer that can trap escaping water?
What is a theory about how water arrived on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Water was present on Earth when the rock formed and was unable to remain until hundreds of millions of years later.

options.label: B
options.text: Water was brought by ice-bearing comets or asteroids that bombarded the Earth over millions of years.

options.label: C
options.text: Water was formed on Earth through a process called chemical reaction.

options.label: D
options.text: Water was created by the Earth's atmosphere.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of carbonaceous chondrite meteorites that formed shortly after the birth of our solar system?

options.label: A
options.text: They contain water and have a mineral chemical composition that matches rocks on Earth and samples from an asteroid that formed at the same time as our planet.

options.label: B
options.text: They do not contain water and have a different mineral chemical composition.

options.label: C
options.text: They contain water but have a different mineral chemical composition.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not contain water and have the same mineral chemical composition.

multiple-choice.question: What is a possible implication of the theory that the Earth may have accumulated a substantial amount of water early on?

options.label: A
options.text: Life may have formed much later than previously thought.

options.label: B
options.text: Life may have formed much earlier than previously thought.

options.label: C
options.text: The Earth's atmosphere may have formed much earlier than previously thought.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth's oceans may have formed much earlier than previously thought.

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique aspect of the water that runs from our showers, drinking fountains, and faucets?

options.label: A
options.text: It came from a nearby lake or river.

options.label: B
options.text: It underwent a cosmic and chaotic journey to get here.

multiple-choice.question: What is a possible explanation for the presence of water on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Water was present on Earth when the rock formed and was unable to remain until hundreds of millions of years later.

options.label: B
options.text: Water was brought by ice-bearing comets or asteroids that bombarded the Earth over millions of years.

options.label: C
options.text: Water was formed on Earth through a process called outgassing.

options.label: D
options.text: Water was created by the Earth's atmosphere.

title: Can robots be creative? - Gil Weinberg

multiple-choice.question: Who is considered the world's first computer programmer?

options.label: B

title: Platoâ€™s Allegory of the Cave - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the Allegory of the Cave, according to Plato?

options.label: A
options.text: A story about a group of people who are chained in a cave, facing a wall with shadows.

options.label: B
options.text: A description of the ideal society, where people are free to live as they choose.

options.label: C
options.text: A metaphor for the journey of life, where people are constantly climbing upwards.

options.label: D
options.text: A philosophical concept that explains the origin of knowledge.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Allegory of the Cave, according to Plato?

options.label: A
options.text: To describe the ideal society and promote rule by philosopher kings.

options.label: B
options.text: To illustrate the theory of forms and the nature of reality.

options.label: C
options.text: To show that the masses are too stubborn and ignorant to govern themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: To explain the origin of knowledge and the problem of representation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the theory of forms, according to Plato?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that things in the physical world are flawed reflections of ideal forms.

options.label: B
options.text: The concept that things in the physical world are perfect and unchanging.

options.label: C
options.text: The notion that things in the physical world are created by a creator.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that things in the physical world are mere illusions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the Allegory of the Cave, according to Plato?

options.label: A
options.text: That people are born with knowledge and understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: That people are born ignorant and must learn through experience.

options.label: C
options.text: That people are born with a natural inclination towards truth and understanding.

options.label: D
options.text: That people are born with a natural inclination towards ignorance and confusion.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the prisoner who is freed from the cave?

options.label: A
options.text: He represents the philosopher who seeks truth and understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: He represents the masses who are content with their ignorance.

options.label: C
options.text: He represents the ruler who seeks power and control.

options.label: D
options.text: He represents the creator who brings forth new ideas and concepts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge faced by the prisoner who is freed from the cave?

options.label: A
options.text: He must adjust to the harsh conditions of the outside world.

options.label: B
options.text: He must overcome his own ignorance and confusion.

options.label: C
options.text: He must resist the temptation of returning to the cave.

options.label: D
options.text: He must navigate the complexities of the outside world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the fire in the Allegory of the Cave?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the source of knowledge and understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the source of power and control.

options.label: C
options.text: It represents the source of comfort and security.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the source of confusion and ignorance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the shadows on the wall in the Allegory of the Cave?

options.label: A
options.text: They represent the physical world and its limitations.

options.label: B
options.text: They represent the ideal forms and their perfection.

options.label: C
options.text: They represent the ignorance and confusion of the prisoners.

options.label: D
options.text: They represent the knowledge and understanding of the philosopher.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the Allegory of the Cave, according to Plato?

options.label: A
options.text: That knowledge and understanding are the key to happiness and fulfillment.

options.label: B
options.text: That ignorance and confusion are the keys to happiness and fulfillment.

options.label: C
options.text: That the physical world is the only reality.

options.label: D
options.text: That the ideal forms are the only reality.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Allegory of the Cave in the context of Plato's philosophy?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the culmination of his philosophical ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the foundation of his philosophical ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: It represents a turning point in his philosophical development.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents a departure from his earlier philosophical ideas.

title: Why itâ€™s so hard to cure HIV/AIDS - Janet Iwasa

multiple-choice.question: In 2008, a man was cured of HIV. This was a first and, so far, a last. What is the significance of this event?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that HIV is a harmless virus.

options.label: B
options.text: It proves that HIV can be cured with current treatments.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the first and, so far, the last case of a person being cured of HIV.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a common occurrence for people to be cured of HIV.

multiple-choice.question: How does HIV spread?

options.label: A
options.text: Through air, water, and casual contact.

options.label: B
options.text: Through exchanges of bodily fluids, such as unprotected sex and contaminated needles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary target of HIV in the body?

options.label: B
options.text: Helper T cells, which help defend the body against bacterial and fungal infections.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for HIV's ability to write its genetic code into the genome of infected cells?
What is the term for the stage of HIV infection when the virus continues to replicate and destroy T cells, but the patient may look and feel completely healthy?
What is the primary purpose of antiretroviral therapy?

options.label: B
options.text: To manage levels of HIV and prevent T cell counts from getting low enough for the disease to progress to AIDS.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to cure HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the virus is too complex.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the virus hides out in the DNA of healthy T cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the virus is too simple.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the virus is not contagious.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the major catches of antiretroviral therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is only effective for a short period of time.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is only effective for people who are already sick with AIDS.

options.label: C
options.text: That HIV-positive patients must keep taking their drugs for the rest of their lives.

options.label: D
options.text: That antiretroviral therapy is not available to everyone.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the research approaches being used to develop a true cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a drug to activate all cells harboring the HIV genetic information.

options.label: B
options.text: Using genetic tools to cut the HIV DNA out of cells' genomes altogether.

options.label: C
options.text: Using a combination of both approaches.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the fact that a cure is possible?

options.label: A
options.text: It means that HIV is no longer a threat.

options.label: B
options.text: It means that HIV is a harmless virus.

options.label: C
options.text: It may give us what we need to beat HIV for good.

options.label: D
options.text: It means that HIV is too complex to cure.

title: How does the thyroid manage your metabolism? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: Where is the thyroid located in the body?
What is the primary function of the thyroid gland?

options.label: B
options.text: To make sure that the cells in the body are working properly

multiple-choice.question: What are two important hormones produced by the thyroid gland?
What is the role of the pituitary gland in relation to the thyroid gland?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce hormones that slow down the thyroid gland

options.label: B
options.text: To oversee the thyroid gland's tasks and make sure it knows when to send out its messengers

options.label: C
options.text: To block the thyroid gland's functions

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of hyperthyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: A slower metabolism and weight gain

options.label: B
options.text: A faster metabolism and weight loss

multiple-choice.question: What are symptoms of hyperthyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: Constant hunger, rapid weight loss, and difficulty sleeping

options.label: B
options.text: Slow metabolism, weight gain, and sensitivity to cold

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of hypothyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: A faster metabolism and weight loss

options.label: B
options.text: A slower metabolism and weight gain

multiple-choice.question: What are symptoms of hypothyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: Weight loss, rapid heartbeat, and constant hunger

options.label: B
options.text: Weight gain, sluggishness, sensitivity to cold, and swollen joints

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the thyroid gland in the body?

options.label: C
options.text: To use energy, grow, and reproduce

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a healthy thyroid gland?

options.label: A
options.text: A slow metabolism and weight gain

options.label: B
options.text: A faster metabolism and weight loss

options.label: D
options.text: The body can run smoothly without any issues

title: The law of conservation of mass - Todd Ramsey

multiple-choice.question: What is the law of conservation of mass?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: It is decreased by a small amount.

options.label: B
options.text: They were formed from heavier elements in a star.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They were formed from a combination of energy and mass.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which stars fuse light elements to form heavier elements?
What is the result of a star going supernova?

options.label: C
options.text: The star scatters its elements across space.

multiple-choice.question: According to Carl Sagan, what are we made of?

options.label: A
options.text: We are made of the same elements as the Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: We are made of the same elements as the stars.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: We are made of a combination of elements.

title: Did Shakespeare write his plays? - Natalya St. Clair and Aaron Williams

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what does the phrase "Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and others have greatness thrust upon them" mean?

options.label: A
options.text: That Shakespeare was a great writer who achieved greatness through hard work.

options.label: B
options.text: That Shakespeare's works were written by someone else, and he was just a pseudonym.

options.label: C
options.text: That some people are born with great talents, while others achieve greatness through hard work and determination.

options.label: D
options.text: That Shakespeare's plays were a result of his collaborations with other writers.

options.label: A
options.text: The study of the structure of language

options.label: B
options.text: The study of the history of literature

options.label: C
options.text: The study of the way we speak and write, examining syntax, grammar, semantics, and vocabulary

options.label: D
options.text: The study of the psychology of writers

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea behind stylometry?

options.label: B
options.text: That each writer's style changes over time

options.label: C
options.text: That each writer's style is influenced by their environment

options.label: D
options.text: That each writer's style is determined by their education

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A method of analyzing the structure of language

options.label: D
options.text: A method of studying the history of literature

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The narrator and a family member

options.label: A
options.text: The biggest number on the dice determines the winner.

options.label: B
options.text: The smallest number on the dice determines the winner.

options.label: C
options.text: If the biggest number is one, two, three, or four, player one wins. If the biggest number is five or six, player two wins.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Because player one has two winning numbers.

Why does the narrator say that events like dice rolling are called random?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the outcome is always the same.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the outcome is always different.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the theoretical probability of each outcome can be calculated, but the actual outcome may not be the same.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the outcome is always determined by chance.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the frequency of a specific outcome, like a player two win, if you repeat the random events many, many, many times?

options.label: A
options.text: It gets closer to its theoretical probability.

options.label: B
options.text: It gets farther from its theoretical probability.

options.label: C
options.text: It stays the same as its theoretical probability.

options.text: To mitigate the effects of sonic booms

title: How do your kidneys work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What are the two bean-shaped organs that work as fine-tuned internal sensors in the human body?
What is the main role of the kidneys in the human body?

options.label: C
options.text: To dispose of waste products and turn them into urine

options.label: D
options.text: To filter the blood and regulate body temperature

multiple-choice.question: How many times does the body's eight liters of blood pass through the kidneys each day?
What is the name of the powerful piece of equipment that works like a sieve in the kidneys to filter the blood?
What happens to the ingredients in the blood that are detected by the tubules in the kidneys?

options.label: A
options.text: They are absorbed back into the blood

options.label: C
options.text: They are stored in the liver

options.label: D
options.text: They are released into the stomach

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the tubes that empty the contents of the kidneys into the bladder to be discharged?
What happens to the urine in the bladder?

options.label: A
options.text: It is absorbed back into the blood

options.label: B
options.text: It is excreted from the body through the ureters

options.label: C
options.text: It is stored in the kidneys

options.label: D
options.text: It is released into the stomach

multiple-choice.question: What hormone is released by the kidneys to increase red blood cell production?
What would happen to the body's fluid levels if the kidneys were not functioning properly?

options.label: D
options.text: They would spiral out of control

multiple-choice.question: How many kidneys does the human body have?

title: Why Shakespeare loved iambic pentameter - David T. Freeman and Gregory Taylor

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most important things in Shakespeare's language?
What is the term for a certain number of stressed and unstressed syllables forming a distinct unit in a line of verse?
What is a dactyl?

options.label: A
options.text: A metrical foot of two syllables with the first unstressed and the second stressed.

options.label: B
options.text: A metrical foot of three syllables with the first stressed and the second and third unstressed.

options.label: C
options.text: A metrical foot of four syllables with the first stressed and the second, third, and fourth unstressed.

options.label: D
options.text: A metrical foot of five syllables with the first stressed and the second, third, fourth, and fifth unstressed.

multiple-choice.question: What is iambic pentameter?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of meter that consists of five iambs per line.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of meter that consists of five dactyls per line.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of meter that consists of five trochees per line.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of meter that consists of five anapests per line.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a stressed syllable followed by an unstressed one in a metrical foot?
What is the term for a line of verse that is made up of several feet?
Why did Shakespeare choose iambic pentameter for his most poetic lines?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was easy for his actors to memorize and for the audience to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was the most common type of meter in the English language.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it followed the natural rhythm of the human heart.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was the most complex type of meter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a metrical foot that consists of an unstressed syllable followed by a stressed syllable?
What is the term for a line of verse that consists of five iambs?
Why did Shakespeare's characters often switch to iambic pentameter when speaking about their emotions and their place in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was a way to express their passion and intensity.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was a way to convey their introspection and contemplation.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was a way to follow the natural rhythm of the human heart.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was a way to show their momentous and significant thoughts.

title: Why do buildings fall in earthquakes? - Vicki V. May

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of building collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: The earthquake itself causes the building to collapse.

options.label: B
options.text: The ground beneath the building shakes violently and splits apart.

options.label: C
options.text: The building's foundation is displaced, sending shock waves through the structure and causing it to vibrate back and forth.

options.label: D
options.text: The building's material type and shape of its columns cause it to collapse.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main factors that determine the strength of a building's oscillation during an earthquake?

options.label: B
options.text: The building's material type and the shape of its columns.

options.label: C
options.text: The building's height and the type of soil it is built on.

options.label: D
options.text: The earthquake's frequency and the building's natural frequency.

multiple-choice.question: What happened in Mexico City during the 1985 earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: Many buildings between six and fifteen stories tall collapsed.

options.label: B
options.text: Buildings taller than fifteen stories were less damaged.

options.label: C
options.text: The earthquake itself caused the building to collapse.

options.label: D
options.text: The building's material type and shape of its columns caused it to collapse.

multiple-choice.question: What is resonance, and how does it relate to building collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: Resonance is a phenomenon where the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves matches the natural frequency of the building, causing it to vibrate more violently.

options.label: B
options.text: Resonance is a phenomenon where the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves is slower than the natural frequency of the building, causing it to vibrate less violently.

options.label: C
options.text: Resonance is a phenomenon where the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves is faster than the natural frequency of the building, causing it to vibrate more violently.

options.label: D
options.text: Resonance is a phenomenon where the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves does not match the natural frequency of the building, causing it to vibrate less violently.

multiple-choice.question: What is base isolation, and how does it help prevent building collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: Base isolation is a method of anchoring the building to the ground to prevent it from moving during an earthquake.

options.label: B
options.text: Base isolation is a method of using flexible layers to isolate the foundation's displacement from the rest of the building.

options.label: C
options.text: Base isolation is a method of using a tuned mass damper system to cancel out resonance and reduce vibrations.

options.label: D
options.text: Base isolation is a method of using a seismic wave absorber to reduce the impact of the earthquake on the building.

multiple-choice.question: What is a tuned mass damper system, and how does it help prevent building collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: A tuned mass damper system is a method of anchoring the building to the ground to prevent it from moving during an earthquake.

options.label: B
options.text: A tuned mass damper system is a method of using a seismic wave absorber to reduce the impact of the earthquake on the building.

options.label: C
options.text: A tuned mass damper system is a method of using flexible layers to isolate the foundation's displacement from the rest of the building.

options.label: D
options.text: A tuned mass damper system is a method of using a system that oscillates out of phase with the natural frequency of the building to reduce vibrations.

title: Why the Arctic is climate change's canary in the coal mine - William Chapman

multiple-choice.question: What is the Arctic described as in terms of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: A stable system with no feedback processes.

options.label: B
options.text: The canary in the coal mine, where tiny changes can have a big impact.

options.label: C
options.text: A region with no impact on the rest of the planet.

options.label: D
options.text: A region with a warming pattern that is not affected by climate change.

multiple-choice.question: What type of climate feedback involves reflectivity?

options.label: C
options.text: Feedback involving the melting of ice.

options.label: D
options.text: Feedback involving the formation of clouds.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the Arctic warms just a little and some of the snow and ice melts?

options.label: A
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath absorb more heat, causing more melting.

options.label: B
options.text: The increased heat causes more freezing, increasing the amount of reflective snow and ice.

options.label: C
options.text: The melting of ice causes a type of negative feedback by releasing moisture into the atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: The melting of ice causes a type of positive feedback by trapping more sunlight.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of Arctic sea ice in another feedback mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: It acts as a buffer between the frigid arctic air and the relatively warmer water underneath.

options.label: B
options.text: It traps more sunlight, causing more melting.

options.label: C
options.text: It releases moisture into the atmosphere, causing more cloud formation.

options.label: D
options.text: It absorbs more heat, causing more warming.

multiple-choice.question: What type of feedback loop is when the initial change leads to effects that work in the opposite direction?

options.label: C
options.text: Feedback involving the melting of ice.

options.label: D
options.text: Feedback involving the formation of clouds.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the increased moisture and clouds present in the Arctic atmosphere block more sunlight?

options.label: C
options.text: The surface warms up by trapping the Earth's heat.

options.label: D
options.text: The surface cools down by releasing more heat.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of positive feedback loops on a system?

options.label: A
options.text: They encourage stability by pushing a system towards equilibrium.

options.label: B
options.text: They destabilize a system by enabling larger and larger deviations.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no impact on a system.

options.label: D
options.text: They cause a system to oscillate between different states.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the temperature differences between the North Pole and the equator on a warming planet?
What are the consequences of the reduced temperature differences between the North Pole and the equator?

options.label: A
options.text: Slower jet stream winds and less linear atmospheric circulation in the middle latitudes.

options.label: B
options.text: Faster jet stream winds and more linear atmospheric circulation in the middle latitudes.

options.label: C
options.text: No impact on atmospheric circulation in the middle latitudes.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased temperature differences between the North Pole and the equator.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to shifts in weather patterns on a warming planet?

options.label: A
options.text: They become less extreme and shorter-lived.

options.label: B
options.text: They become more extreme and longer-lived.

title: The great conspiracy against Julius Caesar - Kathryn Tempest

multiple-choice.question: What would you do if you thought your country was on the path to tyranny?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to stop the leader who is gaining too much power.

options.label: B
options.text: Join the leader who is gaining too much power.

options.label: C
options.text: Stay neutral and not get involved.

options.label: D
options.text: Support the leader who is gaining too much power.

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason behind Roman Senator Marcus Junius Brutus's actions in 44 BCE?

options.label: A
options.text: He wanted to gain more power and wealth.

options.label: B
options.text: He wanted to overthrow the tyrannical king Tarquin the Proud.

options.label: C
options.text: He feared a return to the monarchy and wanted to stop Julius Caesar's rise to power.

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to avenge his family's death.

multiple-choice.question: What was Julius Caesar's role in Roman politics at the time of his assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a senator who opposed the monarchy.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a dictator who had been granted emergency powers.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a consul who had defeated his rival Pompey the Great.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a king who had been overthrown by the people.

multiple-choice.question: Who was the leader of the conspiracy to assassinate Julius Caesar?
How many times was Julius Caesar stabbed before he died?
What was the outcome of the power vacuum that followed Julius Caesar's assassination?

options.label: B
options.text: The concentration of power under the office of Emperor occurred.

options.label: D
options.text: The Roman Senate gained more power.

multiple-choice.question: What is the conflicting legacy of Roman Senator Marcus Junius Brutus?

options.label: A
options.text: He is remembered as a selfless fighter against dictatorship.

options.label: B
options.text: He is remembered as an opportunistic traitor.

options.label: C
options.text: He is remembered as a benevolent leader.

options.label: D
options.text: He is remembered as a tyrannical king.

multiple-choice.question: What are the questions about the price of liberty, the conflict between personal loyalties and universal ideals, and unintended consequences that remain relevant today?

options.label: A
options.text: They are questions about the Roman Empire.

options.label: B
options.text: They are questions about the assassination of Julius Caesar.

options.label: C
options.text: They are questions about the legacy of Marcus Junius Brutus.

options.label: D
options.text: They are questions about the importance of liberty and the conflict between personal loyalties and universal ideals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the phrase "Et tu, Brute?" in the context of Julius Caesar's assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a phrase that means "And you, child?"

options.label: B
options.text: It is a phrase that means "And you, Brutus?"

options.label: C
options.text: It is a phrase that means "And you, friend?"

options.label: D
options.text: It is a phrase that is not relevant to the context of Julius Caesar's assassination.

title: How do the lungs work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of breathing?

options.label: A
options.text: To clear the body of toxins.

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the system that controls the body's vital functions, including breathing?
What happens to the diaphragm and intercostal muscles when the body prepares to take in oxygen-rich air?
What is the name of the tubes that branch off from the trachea and lead to the lungs?
What is the name of the tiny air sacs at the end of each bronchiole where gas exchange occurs?
What is the process by which oxygen and carbon dioxide molecules move from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration?
What happens to the hemoglobin in the capillaries as oxygen crosses over from the alveoli?

options.label: A
options.text: It unloads oxygen and picks up carbon dioxide.

options.label: B
options.text: It grabs oxygen and unloads carbon dioxide.

options.label: D
options.text: It moves to a different location.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the autonomic nervous system in exhaling carbon dioxide-rich air?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the diaphragm to contract and the intercostal muscles to relax.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the diaphragm to relax and the intercostal muscles to contract.

multiple-choice.question: How many liters of air do lungs inhale and exhale each day?
How many times do lungs inhale and exhale per minute?
